conclusion: The dipole consists of two charges, +q and -q, connected by a rod of length d.
The dipole is initially aligned along the X-axis with an angular velocity ω0.
The magnetic field B is perpendicular to the XY-plane.
The initial velocity of the center of mass is zero (v0 = 0).
The magnetic torque τ on a dipole in a magnetic field is given by τ = μ × B.
The magnetic moment μ is q · d, where d is the vector pointing from the negative to the positive charge along the rod.
The moment of inertia I of the dipole about the center of mass is I = 2m (d/2)^2 = 1/2 m d^2.
The initial angular momentum L of the dipole is L = I ω0 = 1/2 m d^2 ω0.
For the dipole to reverse its orientation, the torque due to the magnetic field must be sufficient to change the angular momentum from 1/2 m d^2 ω0 to -1/2 m d^2 ω0.
The work done by the magnetic torque in rotating the dipole by π radians (180 degrees) is W = ∫_0^π τ dθ.
Assuming a constant magnetic moment and field, the torque is constant: τ = qd B.
The change in kinetic energy must equal the work done by the torque: ΔKE = W = qd B π.
To find ω_min, equate the initial angular kinetic energy to the work done: 1/2 I ω_min^2 = qd B π.
Solving for ω_min: 1/4 m d^2 ω_min^2 = qd B π.
ω_min^2 = 4 qd B π / m d^2.
ω_min^2 = 4 q B π / m d.
ω_min = √(4 q B π / m d).
The minimum initial angular velocity necessary for the dipole to reverse its orientation is ω_min = √(4 q B π / m d).
